natural problem: Two fair, six-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability that the sum of the two numbers showing is between 3 and 11, inclusive?
natural solution: We instead find the probability that the sum of the numbers showing is not between 3 and 11. Since each die's face contains the numbers 1-6, we see that this can only be the case if we roll two 1s or two 6s.
Thus the chance that the sum is not between 3 and 11 is $\frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{1}{6} + \frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{1}{6}$, or $\frac{1}{18}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "int set" and dice1 dice2 :: int
assumes h0 : "A = {1..6}"
and h1 : "B = {1..6}"
and h2 : "dice1 \<in> A"
and h3 : "dice2 \<in> B"
shows  "P (\<lambda>(x, y). x + y \<ge> 3 \<and> x + y \<le> 11) (set_of_dice_outcomes A B) = 17 / 18"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair, six-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability that the sum of the two numbers showing is between 3 and 11, inclusive? The final Answer is \frac{17}{18}
 ### Proof
 We instead find the probability that the sum of the numbers showing is not between 3 and 11. Since each die's face contains the numbers 1-6, we see that this can only be the case if we roll two 1s or two 6s.
 Thus the chance that the sum is not between 3 and 11 is $\frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{1}{6} + \frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{1}{6}$, or $\frac{1}{18}$.
 So our desired probability is $1-\frac{1}{18} = \boxed{\frac{17}{18}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "int set" and dice1 dice2 :: int
assumes h0 : "A = {1..6}"
and h1 : "B = {1..6}"
and h2 : "dice1 \<in> A"
and h3 : "dice2 \<in> B"
shows  "P (\<lambda>(x, y). x + y \<ge> 3 \<and> x + y \<le> 11) (set_of_dice_outcomes A B) = 17 / 18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Two dice, each with faces numbered from 1 to 6, are rolled. What is the probability that the sum of the numbers on the two dice is between 3 and 11, inclusive? The final answer is $\frac{17}{18}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i j. i \<in> {1..6} \<and> j \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> P i j = 1 / 36"
and h1 : "\<forall>i j. i \<notin> {1..6} \<or> j \<notin> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> P i j = 0"
shows  "(\<Sum>i\<in>{1..6}. \<Sum>j\<in>{1..6}. if 3 \<le> i + j \<and> i + j \<le> 11 then P i j else 0) = 17 / 18"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair, six-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability that the sum of the two numbers showing is between 3 and 11, inclusive? The final Answer is \frac{17}{18}
 ### Proof
 We instead find the probability that the sum of the numbers showing is not between 3 and 11. Since each die's face contains the numbers 1-6, we see that this can only be the case if we roll two 1s or two 6s.
 Thus the chance that the sum is not between 3 and 11 is $\frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{1}{6} + \frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{1}{6}$, or $\frac{1}{18}$.
 So our desired probability is $1-\frac{1}{18} = \boxed{\frac{17}{18}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i j. i \<in> {1..6} \<and> j \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> P i j = 1 / 36"
and h1 : "\<forall>i j. i \<notin> {1..6} \<or> j \<notin> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> P i j = 0"
shows  "(\<Sum>i\<in>{1..6}. \<Sum>j\<in>{1..6}. if 3 \<le> i + j \<and> i + j \<le> 11 then P i j else 0) = 17 / 18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: There is a probability distribution $P(i, j)$ such that for any two integers $i$ and $j$ between 1 and 6, inclusive, $P(i, j) = \frac{1}{36}$. If either $i$ or $j$ is not in the range 1 to 6, inclusive, then $P(i, j) = 0$. Find the sum of all probabilities $P(i, j)$ for which the sum of $i$ and $j$ is between 3 and 11, inclusive. The final answer is $\frac{17}{18}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "int set"
and prob_A :: "real"
and prob_B :: "real"
assumes h0 : "A = {1..6}"
and h1 : "B = {1..6}"
and h2 : "prob_A = 1 / 6"
and h3 : "prob_B = 1 / 6"
and h4 : "card A = 6"
and h5 : "card B = 6"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> (a, b). prob_A * prob_B) (SIGMA a:A. B) = 17 / 18"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair, six-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability that the sum of the two numbers showing is between 3 and 11, inclusive? The final Answer is \frac{17}{18}
 ### Proof
 We instead find the probability that the sum of the numbers showing is not between 3 and 11. Since each die's face contains the numbers 1-6, we see that this can only be the case if we roll two 1s or two 6s.
 Thus the chance that the sum is not between 3 and 11 is $\frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{1}{6} + \frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{1}{6}$, or $\frac{1}{18}$.
 So our desired probability is $1-\frac{1}{18} = \boxed{\frac{17}{18}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "int set"
and prob_A :: "real"
and prob_B :: "real"
assumes h0 : "A = {1..6}"
and h1 : "B = {1..6}"
and h2 : "prob_A = 1 / 6"
and h3 : "prob_B = 1 / 6"
and h4 : "card A = 6"
and h5 : "card B = 6"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> (a, b). prob_A * prob_B) (SIGMA a:A. B) = 17 / 18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Two dice are rolled, one from set A and one from set B. Set A contains the numbers {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} and set B also contains the numbers {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}. The probability of rolling a specific number from set A is $\frac{1}{6}$ and the probability of rolling a specific number from set B is also $\frac{1}{6}$. What is the probability of rolling any pair of numbers from set A and set B? The final answer is $\frac{17}{18}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> probability"
and h1 : "probability \<le> 1"
and h2 : "probability = (\<Sum>i\<in>{3..11}. \<Sum>j\<in>{1..6}. \<Sum>k\<in>{1..6}. (if i = j + k then 1 else 0)) / 36"
shows  "probability = 17 / 18"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair, six-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability that the sum of the two numbers showing is between 3 and 11, inclusive? The final Answer is \frac{17}{18}
 ### Proof
 We instead find the probability that the sum of the numbers showing is not between 3 and 11. Since each die's face contains the numbers 1-6, we see that this can only be the case if we roll two 1s or two 6s.
 Thus the chance that the sum is not between 3 and 11 is $\frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{1}{6} + \frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{1}{6}$, or $\frac{1}{18}$.
 So our desired probability is $1-\frac{1}{18} = \boxed{\frac{17}{18}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> probability"
and h1 : "probability \<le> 1"
and h2 : "probability = (\<Sum>i\<in>{3..11}. \<Sum>j\<in>{1..6}. \<Sum>k\<in>{1..6}. (if i = j + k then 1 else 0)) / 36"
shows  "probability = 17 / 18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find the probability of the sum of two dice rolls being between 3 and 11, inclusive. The final answer is $\frac{17}{18}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes dice1 dice2 :: "int set"
and P :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "dice1 = {1..6}"
and h1 : "dice2 = {1..6}"
and h2 : "card dice1 = 6"
and h3 : "card dice2 = 6"
and h4 : "\<forall>n \<in> dice1. P n = 1 / 6"
and h5 : "\<forall>n \<in> dice2. P n = 1 / 6"
and h6 : "indep_vars (\<lambda>_. borel) P {dice1, dice2}"
shows  "prob {x+y |x y. x \<in> dice1 \<and> y \<in> dice2 \<and> 3 \<le> x + y \<and> x + y \<le> 11} = 17 / 18"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair, six-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability that the sum of the two numbers showing is between 3 and 11, inclusive? The final Answer is \frac{17}{18}
 ### Proof
 We instead find the probability that the sum of the numbers showing is not between 3 and 11. Since each die's face contains the numbers 1-6, we see that this can only be the case if we roll two 1s or two 6s.
 Thus the chance that the sum is not between 3 and 11 is $\frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{1}{6} + \frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{1}{6}$, or $\frac{1}{18}$.
 So our desired probability is $1-\frac{1}{18} = \boxed{\frac{17}{18}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes dice1 dice2 :: "int set"
and P :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "dice1 = {1..6}"
and h1 : "dice2 = {1..6}"
and h2 : "card dice1 = 6"
and h3 : "card dice2 = 6"
and h4 : "\<forall>n \<in> dice1. P n = 1 / 6"
and h5 : "\<forall>n \<in> dice2. P n = 1 / 6"
and h6 : "indep_vars (\<lambda>_. borel) P {dice1, dice2}"
shows  "prob {x+y |x y. x \<in> dice1 \<and> y \<in> dice2 \<and> 3 \<le> x + y \<and> x + y \<le> 11} = 17 / 18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Two fair six-sided dice (with faces numbered from 1 to 6) are rolled. What is the probability that the sum of the numbers on the faces of the two dice is between 3 and 11, inclusive? The final answer is $\frac{17}{18}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "probability = (1::real) / 6"
and h1 : "2 * h0 \<le> probability \<and> probability \<le> 5 * h0"
shows  "17 / 18 = (\<Sum> i \<in> {3..11}. probability ^ 2)"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair, six-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability that the sum of the two numbers showing is between 3 and 11, inclusive? The final Answer is \frac{17}{18}
 ### Proof
 We instead find the probability that the sum of the numbers showing is not between 3 and 11. Since each die's face contains the numbers 1-6, we see that this can only be the case if we roll two 1s or two 6s.
 Thus the chance that the sum is not between 3 and 11 is $\frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{1}{6} + \frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{1}{6}$, or $\frac{1}{18}$.
 So our desired probability is $1-\frac{1}{18} = \boxed{\frac{17}{18}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "probability = (1::real) / 6"
and h1 : "2 * h0 \<le> probability \<and> probability \<le> 5 * h0"
shows  "17 / 18 = (\<Sum> i \<in> {3..11}. probability ^ 2)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: A die is rolled twice. Let the probability of rolling any given number be $\frac{1}{6}$. Find the probability of rolling a number between 3 and 11 (inclusive) in these two rolls. The final answer is $\frac{17}{18}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum> (i, j)\<in>{(i::nat, j::nat) | 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 6}. indicator {(i, j). 3 \<le> i + j \<and> i + j \<le> 11} (i, j)) / (\<Sum> (i, j)\<in>{(i::nat, j::nat) | 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 6}. 1)"
shows  "P = 17 / 18"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair, six-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability that the sum of the two numbers showing is between 3 and 11, inclusive? The final Answer is \frac{17}{18}
 ### Proof
 We instead find the probability that the sum of the numbers showing is not between 3 and 11. Since each die's face contains the numbers 1-6, we see that this can only be the case if we roll two 1s or two 6s.
 Thus the chance that the sum is not between 3 and 11 is $\frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{1}{6} + \frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{1}{6}$, or $\frac{1}{18}$.
 So our desired probability is $1-\frac{1}{18} = \boxed{\frac{17}{18}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum> (i, j)\<in>{(i::nat, j::nat) | 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 6}. indicator {(i, j). 3 \<le> i + j \<and> i + j \<le> 11} (i, j)) / (\<Sum> (i, j)\<in>{(i::nat, j::nat) | 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 6}. 1)"
shows  "P = 17 / 18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Consider a 6x6 grid with cell coordinates (i, j) where 1 ≤ i ≤ 6 and 1 ≤ j ≤ 6. Let P be the probability that the sum of the coordinates (i + j) of a randomly chosen cell is between 3 and 11, inclusive. What is the value of P? The final answer is $\frac{17}{18}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<Sum>x\<in>{(a, b). a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> a + b \<ge> 3 \<and> a + b \<le> 11}. 1) / (\<Sum>x\<in>{(a, b). a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6}}. 1)"
shows  "probability = 17/18"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair, six-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability that the sum of the two numbers showing is between 3 and 11, inclusive? The final Answer is \frac{17}{18}
 ### Proof
 We instead find the probability that the sum of the numbers showing is not between 3 and 11. Since each die's face contains the numbers 1-6, we see that this can only be the case if we roll two 1s or two 6s.
 Thus the chance that the sum is not between 3 and 11 is $\frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{1}{6} + \frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{1}{6}$, or $\frac{1}{18}$.
 So our desired probability is $1-\frac{1}{18} = \boxed{\frac{17}{18}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<Sum>x\<in>{(a, b). a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> a + b \<ge> 3 \<and> a + b \<le> 11}. 1) / (\<Sum>x\<in>{(a, b). a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6}}. 1)"
shows  "probability = 17/18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Two dice with faces numbered from 1 to 6 are rolled. What is the probability that the sum of the numbers on the two dice is between 3 and 11, inclusive? The final answer is $\frac{17}{18}$.

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum>(a, b)\<in>{(a::nat, b::nat) | a. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> a + b \<ge> 3 \<and> a + b \<le> 11}. 1) / 36"
shows  "P = 17 / 18"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair, six-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability that the sum of the two numbers showing is between 3 and 11, inclusive? The final Answer is \frac{17}{18}
 ### Proof
 We instead find the probability that the sum of the numbers showing is not between 3 and 11. Since each die's face contains the numbers 1-6, we see that this can only be the case if we roll two 1s or two 6s.
 Thus the chance that the sum is not between 3 and 11 is $\frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{1}{6} + \frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{1}{6}$, or $\frac{1}{18}$.
 So our desired probability is $1-\frac{1}{18} = \boxed{\frac{17}{18}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum>(a, b)\<in>{(a::nat, b::nat) | a. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> a + b \<ge> 3 \<and> a + b \<le> 11}. 1) / 36"
shows  "P = 17 / 18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find the probability $P$ of the sum of two dice being between 3 and 11, inclusive. The final answer is $\frac{17}{18}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "finite {1..6::int}"
and h1 : "finite {1..6}"
and h2 : "card {1..6} = 6"
and h3 : "prob_space P"
and h4 : "indep_events P {1..6} {1..6}"
and h5 : "P {1..6} = 1/6"
shows  "P {x+y | x y. x \<in> {1..6} \<and> y \<in> {1..6} \<and> 3 \<le> x+y \<and> x+y \<le> 11} = 17/18"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair, six-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability that the sum of the two numbers showing is between 3 and 11, inclusive? The final Answer is \frac{17}{18}
 ### Proof
 We instead find the probability that the sum of the numbers showing is not between 3 and 11. Since each die's face contains the numbers 1-6, we see that this can only be the case if we roll two 1s or two 6s.
 Thus the chance that the sum is not between 3 and 11 is $\frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{1}{6} + \frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{1}{6}$, or $\frac{1}{18}$.
 So our desired probability is $1-\frac{1}{18} = \boxed{\frac{17}{18}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "finite {1..6::int}"
and h1 : "finite {1..6}"
and h2 : "card {1..6} = 6"
and h3 : "prob_space P"
and h4 : "indep_events P {1..6} {1..6}"
and h5 : "P {1..6} = 1/6"
shows  "P {x+y | x y. x \<in> {1..6} \<and> y \<in> {1..6} \<and> 3 \<le> x+y \<and> x+y \<le> 11} = 17/18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: In a fair six-sided dice game, the probability of each number from 1 to 6 is $\frac{1}{6}$. If two dice are rolled and their sum is between 3 and 11 (inclusive), what is the probability of this event occurring? The final answer is $\frac{17}{18}$.
